Thus is Floire in some sense another Eneas, and his function within the gender hierarchy of Old French romance bears further scrutiny in terms of recent analyses that show how the hero's relation to territory in the Eneas reinscribes male homosocial bonds and imagines erotic relations between men, against the grain of the heterosexual love story
